replication_study.hypothesis: Controlling for a linear time trend and city-specific random intercepts, the introduction of social distancing (lockdown=1) is associated with an additional decrease of approximately 23 percentage points in the Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) relative to days without such measures.

data_plan.source_type: Aggregated mobility indices (Citymapper Mobility Index) and policy implementation indicators compiled from media/government sources.
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Panel of cities over March 2–March 26, 2020 (25 days per city in this dataset).
data_plan.access_details: Local file provided in replication_data; analysis assumes the same file will be available at /app/data/replicationDataset_Malik2020_with.year.csv at runtime.

qualification.explanation: The dataset includes the same key constructs as the original (CMI outcome and lockdown indicators), enabling a close replication of the original multilevel mixed-effects analysis. It is sufficiently different as it covers 39 (not 41) cities, constituting a distinct sample while preserving the original study design.
qualification.similarity_to_original: Original study used CMI and policy dates for 41 cities, March 2–26, 2020, and a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression (post_registration.json; original_paper.pdf). The replication dataset contains CMI (CMI column) and policy indicators (lockdown, completeLockdown) with the same temporal window and daily granularity (dataDictionary.xlsx - Sheet1.csv; replicationDataset_Malik2020_with.year.csv).
qualification.deviation_from_original: Original sample size: 1,025 observations across 41 cities (25 per city) from March 2–26, 2020 (post_registration.json; original_paper.pdf). Replication dataset: 975 observations across 39 cities (25 per city), implying two cities fewer than the original (replicationDataset_Malik2020_with.year.csv; city unique categories=39).

data_plan.notes: The dataset includes additional Google mobility variables (CMRT_*), not necessary for the focal replication. Column EXTRAS is empty. date is a string and is parsed to datetime in the code. CMI is integer percentage of baseline trips. lockdown and completeLockdown are binary indicators based on Malik et al. (2020) compilation (dataDictionary.xlsx - Sheet1.csv).

steps: Parse date to datetime and sort by date and city.
Construct day_index as days since the first date in the dataset (expected 2020-03-02).
Fit a multilevel mixed-effects linear model with random intercepts by city: CMI ~ day_index + lockdown.
Optionally estimate an extended model including completeLockdown: CMI ~ day_index + lockdown + completeLockdown.
Extract coefficients, p-values, and 95% confidence intervals; save to /app/data/replication_results.json and /app/data/replication_model_summary.txt.
planned_method.models: Multilevel mixed-effects linear regression with random intercepts for city (no random slopes), ML estimation (reml=False).
planned_method.outcome_variable: CMI (Citymapper Mobility Index; percent of baseline planned trips).
planned_method.independent_variables: day_index (linear time trend), lockdown (binary policy indicator), optional completeLockdown (binary intensity indicator).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Coefficient on lockdown capturing the additional level reduction in CMI associated with social distancing measures, controlling for time trend and city random effects.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: t-tests on coefficients from mixed-effects model; 95% confidence intervals.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion (statsmodels default). The provided dataset has no missing values for the analysis variables.
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: Not applicable; single focal outcome and primary coefficient.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Primary success if lockdown coefficient is negative and of similar magnitude to the original (≈ −23 percentage points) with 95% CI excluding zero; secondary check that the day_index coefficient is negative and around −3.4 percentage points per day.

files.replication_data/replicate_analysis.py: Entry-point script. Reads /app/data/replicationDataset_Malik2020_with.year.csv, parses dates, constructs day_index, fits mixed-effects models (CMI ~ day_index + lockdown [+ completeLockdown]), and writes outputs to /app/data/replication_results.json and /app/data/replication_model_summary.txt.

codebase.notes: All IO paths are hard-coded to /app/data as required. statsmodels MixedLM is used to implement multilevel mixed-effects regression with random intercepts for cities. No non-Python scripts were provided; no translation needed.

analysis.instructions: 1) Place replicationDataset_Malik2020_with.year.csv in ./data so it is available inside the container at /app/data. 2) Run: python replication_data/replicate_analysis.py. 3) Inspect /app/data/replication_results.json and /app/data/replication_model_summary.txt for estimates. The focal estimate is the coefficient on lockdown in model_1.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare the lockdown coefficient magnitude and 95% CI to the original −23% (95% CI: −27%, −20%) and verify negative direction. Also compare the day_index coefficient to the original daily decline of −3.4% (95% CI: −3.6%, −3.3%).
